ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies to encode the source code in a data set.

Specifies printing a message for each statement in a program as it is executed. 
This option produces extensive output.

Syntax: LIBRARY | INLIB=library.dataset 
      LIBRARY | INLIB=((library-1.dataset library-2.dataset ... library-n.dataset) 
      LIBRARY | INLIB=library.datasetM - library.datasetN 

Specifies that previously compiled libraries are to be linked into the program.
Specifies that both the LISTSOURCE and the LISTPROG options are in effect.
Specifies that the LISTCODE, LISTPROG, and LISTSOURCE options are in effect.
Specifies that the compiled program code be printed. LISTCODE lists the chain of operations that are generated by the compiler.
Specifies that prototypes for all visible FCMP functions or subroutines be written to the SAS listing.

Specifies that the compiled program be printed. The listing for assignment statements is generated
from the chain of operations that are generated by the compiler.
The source statement text is printed for other statements.
Specifies that source code statements for the program be printed.

[Syntax: OUTLIB=libname.dataset.package] 
      
Specifies the three-level name of an output data set to which the compiled subroutines 
and functions are written when the PROC FCMP step ends.

Specifies printing the result of each statement in a program as it is executed. 
This option produces extensive output.

Specifies printing the results of each operation in each statement in a program 
 as it is executed.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ABORT; 
      
Terminates the current DATA step, job, or SAS session.

Syntax: ARRAY array-name[dimensions] </NOSYMBOLS | variable(s) | constant(s) | (initial-values)>;
      
Associates a name with a list of variables and constants.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that an array of numeric or character values be created without the associated 
element variables. In this case, the only way you can access elements in the array is by 
array subscripting.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ATTRIB variable(s) <FORMAT=format-name LABEL='label' LENGTH=length>;
      
Specifies format, label, and length information for variables.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: FORMAT=format-name] 
          
Associates a format with variables in the variable argument.

[Syntax: LABEL='label'] 
          
Associates a label with variables in the variable argument.

[Syntax: LENGTH=length] 
          
Specifies the length of the variable in the variable argument.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: DELETEFUNC function-name;

Causes a function to be deleted from the function library that is specified in the OUTLIB option.

Required Argument:
function-name
  specifies the name of a function to be deleted from the function library that is specified in the OUTLIB option.

Syntax: DELETESUBR subroutine-name; 
      
Causes a subroutine to be deleted from the function library that is specified in the OUTLIB option. 

Required Argument: 
subroutine-name
  specifies the name of a subroutine to be deleted from the function library that is specified in the OUTLIB option.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that the function supports a variable number of arguments.
If you specify VARARGS, then the last argument in the function must be an array.

[Syntax: KIND= | GROUP='string'] 
          
Specifies a collection of items that have specific attributes.

Specifies that the subroutine has a variable argument length. In this case, the last 
argument must be an array. The array accepts the variable arguments.
Specifies arguments from the argument list that the subroutine should update.

[Syntax: KIND= | GROUP='string'] 
          
Specifies a collection of items that have specific attributes.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: OUTARGS out-argument-1, ..., out-argument-n; 
      
Specifies arguments from the argument list that the subroutine should update.

Syntax: ENDSUB;
      
Ends a FUNCTION or SUBROUTINE statement block.

Syntax: LABEL variable='label';
      
Specifies a label of up to 256 characters.

Syntax: LISTFUNC function-name; 
      
Causes the source code for a function to be written to the SAS listing.
      
Required Argument:
function-name
  specifies the name of the function for which source code is written to the SAS listing.

Syntax: LISTSUBR subroutine-name;  
      
Causes the source code for a subroutine to be written to the SAS listing.

Required Argument:
subroutine-name
  specifies the name of the subroutine for which source code is written to the SAS listing.

Syntax: STRUCT structure-name variable;
      
Declares (creates) structure types that are defined in C-Language packages.

Syntax: BY <DESCENDING> variable-1 
  <...<DESCENDING> variable-n > <NOTSORTED><GROUPFORMAT>; 
  
Controls the operation of a SET, MERGE, MODIFY, or UPDATE statement in the DATA step and sets up 
special grouping variables.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that the data sets are sorted in descending order by the variable that is specified. 
DESCENDING means largest to smallest numerically, or reverse alphabetical for character variables.

Uses the formatted values, instead of the internal values, of the BY variables to determine where 
BY groups begin and end, and therefore how FIRST.variable and LAST.variable are assigned. Although 
the GROUPFORMAT option can appear anywhere in the BY statement, the option applies to all variables 
in the BY statement.

Specifies that observations with the same BY value are grouped together but are not necessarily 
sorted in alphabetical or numeric order.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: CALL routine(parameter-1<, ...parameter-n>); 
      
Invokes a SAS CALL routine.

Syntax: DATALINES;
      
Specifies that data lines follow.

Syntax: DATALINES4;
      
Indicates that data lines that contain semicolons follow.

Syntax: CONTINUE; 
      
Stops processing the current DO-loop iteration and resumes processing the next iteration.

Syntax: DELETE; 
      
Stops processing the current observation.

Syntax: DESCRIBE;
      
Retrieves source code from a stored compiled DATA step program or a DATA step view.

Syntax: DISPLAY window<.group> <NOINPUT > <BLANK> <BELL > <DELETE>; 
      
Displays a window that is created with the WINDOW statement.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies that you cannot input values into fields that are displayed in the window.
Clears the window.

Produces an audible alarm, beep, or bell sound when the window is displayed if your personal 
computer is equipped with a speaker device that provides sound.

Deletes the display of the window after processing passes from the DISPLAY statement on which 
the option appears.

Executes statements in a DO loop repetitively until a condition is true.
          
Syntax: 
DO UNTIL (expression); 
...more SAS statements...  
END

Separates the start and stop integers or expressions that control the number of times the 
portion of the DATA step between the iterative DO and END statements is processed.

Precedes an increment integer (other than 0) or an expression that generates an integer to be 
added to the value of the index variable in each iteration of the DO loop.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: DROP variable-list; 
      
Excludes variables from output SAS data sets.

Syntax: END; 
      
Ends a DO group or SELECT group processing.

Syntax: ERROR <message>; 
      
Sets _ERROR_ to 1. A message written to the SAS log is optional.

Syntax: EXECUTE;
      
Executes a stored compiled DATA step program.

Syntax: FILE file-specification <device-type> <options> <operating-environment-options>; 
      
Specifies the current output file for PUT statements.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Is a reserved fileref that directs the output that is produced by any PUT statements 
to the SAS log.
[device-type] Specifies that the device is a disk drive.
[device-type] Specifies that the output to the file is discarded. Tip: Specifying DUMMY can be useful for testing.
[device-type] Indicates that the output device type is a graphics device that will receive graphics data.
[device-type] Specifies an unnamed pipe. Note: Some operating environments do not support pipes.
[device-type] Specifies an unbuffered graphics output device.
[device-type] Specifies a printer or printer spool file.
[device-type] Specifies a tape drive.

[device-type] Creates a temporary file that exists only as long as the filename is assigned. 
          
Restriction: Do not specify a physical pathname. If you do, SAS returns an error.
[device-type] Specifies the user's terminal.
[device-type] Specifies a Universal Printing printer definition name.
Specifies the block size of the output file.
Specifies a variable that SAS automatically sets to the current column location of the pointer.
Specifies an alternate delimiter (other than a blank) to be used for LIST output.
Specifies a character string as an alternate delimiter (other than a blank) to be used for LIST output
Specifies a parsing option for the DLMSTR= T option that removes trailing blanks of the string delimiter.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Removes trailing blanks of the string delimiter.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Discards data items that exceed the output line length (as specified by the LINESIZE= or LRECL= options in the FILE statement).
Specifies that data values that contain embedded delimiters, such as tabs or commas, be enclosed in quotation marks.
Specifies the encoding to use when writing to the output file.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Arabic
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Baltic

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Defines a character variable, whose name you supply, that SAS sets to the value 
 of the physical name of the file currently open for PUT statement output.

Defines a variable whose change in value causes the FILE statement to close the current 
output file and open a new one the next time the FILE statement executes.
Causes data that exceeds the current line length to be written on a new line.
Specifies that the currently defined footnotes are printed.
Specifies that the currently defined footnotes are not printed.

Defines a statement label that identifies a group of SAS statements that you want 
to execute each time SAS begins a new output page

Defines a variable whose value is the current relative line number within the group 
of lines available to the output pointer.

Sets the maximum number of columns per line for reports and the maximum record length 
for data files.
Defines a variable whose value is the number of lines left on the current page.
Specifies the logical record length of the output file.
Writes the output lines after any existing lines in the file.
Specifies the number of lines that you want available to the output pointer in the current iteration of the DATA step.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the number of lines that are available to the output pointer.  Replace n with an integer.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the entire page is available to the output pointer.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ODS < = (ODS-suboptions) >] 
          
Specifies to use the Output Delivery System to format the output from a DATA step.
Replaces the previous contents of the file.

Specifies that records written to an external file are padded with blanks to the 
length that is specified in the LRECL= option.

Specifies that records written to an external file are not padded with blanks to 
the length that is specified in the LRECL= option.

[Syntax: PAGESIZE=value] 
          
Sets the number of lines per page for your reports.

Either a reserved fileref that directs the output that is produced by any PUT statements 
to the same file as the output that is produced by SAS procedures, or an option that 
specifies that carriage-control characters are placed in the output lines.
Specifies that carriage-control characters are placed in the output lines.
Specifies the record format of the output file.

Stops processing the DATA step immediately if a PUT statement attempts to write a data 
item that exceeds the current line length.
Specifies that the current title lines are printed on the pages of files.
Specifies that the current title lines are not printed on the pages of files.

[Syntax: _FILE_=variable] 
          
StatementOptionNames a character variable that references the current output buffer 
of this FILE statement.

[Syntax: DEFAULT=default-format] 
          
Specifies a temporary default format for displaying the values of variables 
that are not listed in the FORMAT statement.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: GOTO label;
      
Jumps to a new statement.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
If the conditions that are specified in the IF clause are met, the IF-THEN statement 
executes a SAS statement for observations that are read from a SAS data set, for 
records in an external file, or for computed values.
DO statement in an IF-THEN construct.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
If the condition in an IF-THEN statement is false and an ELSE statement is present, 
then the ELSE action is carried out.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
If the conditions that are specified in the IF clause are met, the IF-THEN statement 
executes a SAS statement for observations that are read from a SAS data set, for 
records in an external file, or for computed values.
Executes a SAS statement for observations that meet specific conditions.
DO statement in an IF-THEN/ELSE construct.

[Syntax: DEFAULT= default-informat] 
          
Specifies a temporary default informat for reading values of the variables that 
are listed in the INFORMAT statement. If no variable is specified, then the DEFAULT= 
informat specification applies a temporary default informat for reading values of all 
the variables of that type included in the DATA step. Numeric informats are applied 
to numeric variables, and character informats are applied to character variables. 
These default informats apply only to the current DATA step.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: KEEP variable-list; 
      
Specifies the variables to include in output SAS data sets.

Syntax: LEAVE; 
      
Stops processing the current loop and resumes with the next statement in the sequence.

Syntax: LENGTH variable-specification(s)<DEFAULT=n>; 
      
Specifies the number of bytes for storing variables.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: DEFAULT=n] 
          
Changes the default number of bytes that SAS uses to store the values of any 
newly created numeric variables.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: LINK label; 
      
Directs program execution immediately to the statement label that is specified and, 
if followed by a RETURN statement, returns execution to the statement that follows 
the LINK statement.

Syntax: LIST; 
      
Writes to the SAS log the input data record for the observation that is being processed.

Syntax: LOCK libref<.member-name<.member-type | .entry-name.entry-type>> <LIST | QUERY | SHOW | CLEAR> ; 
      
Acquires and releases an exclusive lock on an existing SAS file.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Writes to the SAS log whether you have an exclusive lock on the specified SAS file.

Releases a lock on the specified SAS file that was acquired by using the LOCK statement in your 
SAS session.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: MISSING character(s); 
      
Assigns characters in your input data to represent special missing values for numeric data.

Syntax: OUTPUT<data-set-name(s)>; 
      
Writes the current observation to a SAS data set.

Syntax: PAGE; 
      
Skips to a new page in the SAS log.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Writes the last input data record that is read either from the current input file or 
from the data lines that follow a DATELINES statement.

Writes the values of all variables, which includes automatic variables, that are defined 
in the current DATA step by using named output.

Moves data values for all columns (as defined by the ODS option in the FILE statement) into 
a special buffer, from which it is eventually written to the data component. The ODS option 
in the FILE statement defines the structure of the data component that holds the results of 
the DATA step.

Causes the values that follow the keyword OVERPRINT to print on the most recently written 
output line.

Advances the pointer to the first line of a new page, even when the pointer is positioned 
on the first line and the first column of a new page.

Advances the pointer to the first line of a new page. SAS automatically begins a new 
page when a line exceeds the current PAGESIZE= value.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: PUTLOG 'message'; 
      
Writes a message to the SAS log.

Syntax: REDIRECT INPUT | OUTPUT old-name-1 = new-name-1<... old-name-n = new-name-n>; 
      
Points to different input or output SAS data sets when you execute a stored program.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies to redirect input data sets.
Specifies to redirect output data sets.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: REMOVE <data-set-name(s)>; 
      
Deletes an observation from a SAS data set.

Syntax: RENAME old-name-1=new-name-1 ... <old-name-n=new-name-n>; 
      
Specifies new names for variables in output SAS data sets.

Syntax: REPLACE <data-set-name-1><...data-set-name-n>; 
      
Replaces an observation in the same location.

Syntax: RETAIN <element-list(s) <initial-value(s) | 
  (initial-value-1) | (initial-value-list-1) > 
  < ... element-list-n <initial-value-n | 
  (initial-value-n ) | (initial-value-list-n)>>>; 
  
Causes a variable that is created by an INPUT or assignment statement to retain its value from 
one iteration of the DATA step to the next.

An optional OTHERWISE statement specifies a statement to be executed if no WHEN condition is met. 
An END statement ends a SELECT group.

      
Syntax: 
  <... WHEN-n (when-expression-1 <..., when-expression-n>) statement;>  
    <OTHERWISE statement;>

Syntax: SKIP <n>; 
      
Creates a blank line in the SAS log.

Syntax: STOP; 
      
Stops execution of the current DATA step.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies the color of the window background for operating environments that have this capability. 
In other operating environments, this option affects the color of the window border.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: BLACK
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: GRAY|GREY

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: COLUMNS=columns] 
          
Specifies the number of columns in the window.

[Syntax: ICOLUMN=column] 
          
Specifies the initial column within the monitor at which the window is displayed.

[Syntax: IROW=row] 
          
Specifies the initial row (or line) within the monitor at which the window is displayed.

[Syntax: KEYS=<<libref.>catalog.>keys-entry] 
          
Specifies the name of a KEYS entry that contains the function key definitions 
for the window.

[Syntax: MENU=<<libref.>catalog.>pmenu-entry] 
          
Specifies the name of a menu (pmenu) you have built with the PMENU procedure.

[Syntax: ROWS=rows] 
          
Specifies the number of rows (or lines) in the window.

Syntax: ATTR=attribute | (attribute-1 <... , attribute-n>) 
          
Controls these highlighting attributes of the field:

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes the field to blink.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Displays the field at high intensity.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Displays the field in reverse video.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Controls whether the cursor moves to the next unprotected field of the current window or group 
when you have entered data in all positions of a field.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the cursor moves automatically to the next unprotected field.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the cursor does not move automatically.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Determines whether the macro processor displays the characters you are entering into a macro variable 
value as you enter them.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that SAS displays characters in a field as you type them in.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the entered characters are not displayed.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Controls whether a field is displayed by all executions of a DISPLAY statement in the same iteration 
of the DATA step until the DISPLAY statement contains the BLANK option.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that each execution of the DISPLAY statement displays all previously displayed contents  of the field as well as the contents that are scheduled for display by the current DISPLAY  statement. If the new contents overlap persisting contents, the persisting contents are no  longer displayed.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that each execution of a DISPLAY statement displays only the current contents of the field.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Controls whether information can be entered into a field.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that you cannot enter information.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that you can enter information.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Controls whether a field can be left blank.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that you must enter a value in the field.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that you can leave the field blank.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: GROUP=group] 
          
Specifies a group of related fields.
Closes the LISTING destination and any files that are associated with it.

Syntax: EXCLUDE exclusion(s)| ALL | NONE 
          
Excludes one or more output objects from the LISTING destination.

Syntax: EXCLUDE/SELECT ALL 
          
Excludes/Selects all output objects from the LISTING destination.

Syntax: EXCLUDE/SELECT NONE 
          
Excludes/Selects no output objects from the LISTING destination.

Syntax: SELECT selection(s) | ALL | NONE 
          
Selects output objects for the LISTING destination.
Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

Suggests how to split a table that is too wide to fit on a single page into sections of columns and 
rows. Each section of columns and rows is a data panel. Each data panel has column headings at the top.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Writes the specified number of observations in a panel, if possible. More than one  panel can occur on every page if space permits.   Range: 1 to the largest integer that the operating system supports.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Bases the size of the panel on the way that the table is stored in memory. This value  provides the fastest performance. However, if the table contains many columns, the  number of rows in each panel might be small.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Tries to make panels that match the page size. If the table contains more columns than  can fit on a page, the first page is filled with as many observations as possible for  as many columns as can fit on a single line. The second page contains the same  observations for the next group of columns, and so on, until all rows and columns  have been printed.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: DEVICE= device-driver] 
          
Specifies the name of a device driver. ODS automatically selects an optimal 
default device for each open output destination.

Syntax: FILE=file-specification
          
Specifies the file to write to. file-specification is one of the following:

  'external-file' 
  is the name of an external file to which to write.

  fileref 
  is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file.

Syntax: GPATH= file-specification <(url='Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE)> 

Specifies the location for all graphics output that is generated while the destination is open. 

file-specification 
specifies the file or SAS catalog to which to write. file-specification is one of the following:

    external-file 
    is the name of an external file to write to.
    Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

    fileref 
    is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file.
    
    libref.catalog 
    specifies a SAS catalog to which to write.

URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE 
specifies a URL for file-specification. 

    Uniform-Resource-Locator 
    is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references 
    that it creates to the file.

      Requirement: You must enclose Uniform-Resource-Locator in quotation marks. 

    NONE 
    specifies that no information from the GPATH= option appears in the links or references.

Syntax: URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE 

Specifies a URL for file-specification. 

    Uniform-Resource-Locator 
    is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references 
    that it creates to the file.

      Requirement: You must enclose Uniform-Resource-Locator in quotation marks. 

    NONE 
    specifies that no information from the GPATH= option appears in the links or references.

Specifies the image resolution of ODS graphics output. Output from device-based graphics is not 
affected. Default: 100

[Syntax: PACKAGE <package-name>] 
          
Specifies that the output from the destination be added to a package.
Determines whether you can edit ODS graphics output with the ODS Graphics Editor.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Turns on the ability to edit ODS graphics output with the ODS Graphics Editor.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Turns off the ability to edit ODS graphics output with the ODS Graphics Editor.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Opens, manages, or closes the DOCUMENT destination, which produces a hierarchy of output objects that 
enables you to produce multiple ODS output formats without rerunning a PROC or DATA step. 

Syntax:
(1) ODS DOCUMENT action;  

(2) ODS DOCUMENT  
    <NAME=<libref.>member-name <(access-option)>>  
    <DIR=(<PATH=path<(access-option)> <LABEL="label">> )>  
    <CATALOG=permanent-catalog | _NULL_>;

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: EXCLUDE exclusion(s)| ALL | NONE 
          
Excludes one or more output objects from the DOCUMENT destination.
Closes the destination and any files that are associated with it.
See the EXCLUDE or SELECT option.
See the EXCLUDE or SELECT option.

Syntax: SELECT selection(s) | ALL | NONE 
          
Selects one or more output objects for the DOCUMENT destination.
Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

By default, no value is assigned to CATALOG=, which means that temporary GRSEGs 
are not copied to a permanent catalog.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Copies any temporary GRSEG to the specified permanent catalog and keeps a reference to the permanent  GRSEG in the document. This value persists until the ODS DOCUMENT statement is closed, or until you  delete it by specifying CATALOG=_NULL_.  The permanent catalog has the following form:     <libref.><member-name>;
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Deletes the catalog name that was previously specified for the CATALOG= option. Thereafter, temporary  GRSEGs are not copied into the permanent catalog, and thus are unavailable in subsequent sessions.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: DIR= (<PATH=path <(access-option)>> <LABEL='label'>); 
          
Specifies the directory path and/or label for ODS output. 

LABEL=label 
assigns a label to a path.

PATH= path <(access-option)> 
is specified as a sequence of entries that are delimited by backslashes.

  path can have the form: 

    path<#sequence-number>  
    where path is the name of the path.

    #sequence-number 
    is a number which, when combined with a pathname, uniquely identifies the entry in the directory that 
    contains it. 

  access-option 
  specifies the access mode for the ODS document. 

    WRITE -- opens a document and provides write access as well as read access. 

    UPDATE -- opens an ODS document and appends new content to the document. UPDATE provides update access 
    as well as read access.
Is specified as a sequence of entries that are delimited by backslashes.
Assigns a label to a path.

[access-option] 
          
Opens a document and provides write access as well as read access.

[access-option] 
          
Opens an ODS document and appends new content to the document. UPDATE provides 
update access as well as read access.

Syntax: NAME= <libref.>member-name<(access-option)> 
where:

libref 
specifies the SAS library where the document is stored.

  Default: If no library name is specified, the WORK library is used. 

member-name 
specifies the document name.

access-option 
specifies the access mode for the ODS document. 

  WRITE 
  opens a document and provides write access as well as read access. 

  UPDATE 
  opens an ODS document and appends new content to the document. UPDATE provides update access as well 
  as read access.

Closes the OUTPUT destination. When an ODS destination is closed, ODS does not send output to that 
destination. Closing a destination frees some system resources.
Sets the list for the OUTPUT destination to EXCLUDE ALL.

Writes to the SAS log the current selection or exclusion list for the OUTPUT destination. If the 
list is the default list (EXCLUDE ALL), then SHOW also writes the current overall selection or exclusion list.

Syntax: MATCH_ALL=<macro-var-name> 

Creates a new data set for each output object.

Determines when ODS closes any data sets that it is creating, and determines when ODS removes output 
objects from the selection list for the OUTPUT destination.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Maintains the list of definitions even after the procedure ends, until you explicitly modify it.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Maintains the list of definitions and keeps open the data sets that it is creating even if the  procedure or DATA step ends, or until you explicitly modify the list.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Suppresses the warning that an output object was requested but not created.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ODS GRAPHICS <OFF | ON> </ option(s)>; 
      
 Enables or disables ODS graphics processing and sets graphics environment options. This statement 
 affects ODS template-based graphics only. The ODS GRAPHICS statement does not affect device-based 
 graphics.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Disables ODS Graphics processing.
Enables ODS Graphics processing. This is the default if no argument is used.

StatementHelp.#cdata: Specifies whether anti-aliasing is applied to the rendering of the line and markers in any graph.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Does not smooth jagged edges of components other than text in the graph.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Smooths jagged edges of all components in the graph.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Smooths jagged edges of all components in the graph.
Does not smooth jagged edges of components other than text in the graph.

Specifies the maximum number of markers or lines to be anti-aliased before anti-aliasing is disabled. 
Default: 1000
Specifies whether to draw a border around the graph.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies not to draw a border around the graph.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to draw a border around the graph.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies whether to draw a border around the graph.
Specifies not to draw a border around any graph.
Specifies the maximum number of discrete values to be shown in any graph. Default: 1000

Specifies the maximum number of group values to be shown in any graph. Any graph that supports the 
GROUP= option is affected. Default: 1000
Specifies the height of any graph.

[Syntax: IMAGEFMT=image-file-type | STATIC] 
          
Specifies the image format to be used. If the image format is not valid for the active 
output destination, the format is automatically changed to the default image format for 
that destination.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Microsoft Windows Device Independent Bitmap
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Microsoft Windows Device Independent Bitmap
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip15: Uses the best quality static image format for the active output destination. This is the default.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies to generate data tips.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies not to generate data tips.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to generate data tips.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies to generate data tips.
Specifies not to generate data tips.

[Syntax: IMAGENAME="filename"] 
          
Specifies the base image filename.

[Syntax: LABELMAX= n] 
          
Specifies the maximum number of labeled areas before labeling is disabled. 

Default: 200

[Syntax: MAXLEGENDAREA= n] 
          
Specifies an integer that is interpreted as the maximum percentage of the 
overall graphics area that a legend can occupy. Default: 20

[Syntax: PANELCELLMAX=n] 
          
Specifies the maximum number of cells in a graph panel where the number of 
cells is determined dynamically by classification variables. Default: 10000
Resets all of the options to their defaults.
Resets the specified option to its default value.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Resets all of the reset-options to their defaults.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Resets the ANTIALIAS option to its default.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Resets the ANTIALIASMAX option to its default.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Resets the index counter that is appended to static image files.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Resets the IMAGEMAP= option to its default.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Resets the LABELMAX= option to its default.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip9: Resets the SCALE= option to its default.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip10: Resets the TIPMAX= option to its default.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip11: Resets the WIDTH= option to its default.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Scales the components of graph proportionally.

Does not scale the components of graph proportionally.

tips are disabled. Default: 500

ProcedureStatement.StatementName: ODS MARKUP|ODS HTML|ODS CHTML|ODS HTMLCSS|ODS HTML3|ODS IMODE|ODS PHTML|ODS CSVALL|ODS DOCBOOK|ODS WML

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Opens, manages, or closes the specified destination, which produces SAS output that is formatted using 
one of many different markup languages.
      
Syntax: 
ODS MARKUP|HTML|CHTML|HTMLCSS|HTML3|IMODE|PHTML|CSVALL|DOCBOOK|WML|SASREPORT|TROFF|
  HTML4|LATEX|WMLOLIST<(<ID=>identifier)> <action>;  
ODS MARKUP|HTML|CHTML|HTMLCSS|HTML3|IMODE|PHTML|CSVALL|DOCBOOK|WML|SASREPORT|TROFF|
  HTML4|LATEX|WMLOLIST<(<ID=>identifier)> <option(s)><TAGSET=tagset-name> <action>;

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: EXCLUDE exclusion(s)| ALL | NONE 
          
Excludes one or more output objects from the destination.
Closes the destination and any files that are associated with it.
See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.
See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.

Syntax: SELECT selection(s) | ALL | NONE 
          
Selects one or more output objects for the specified destination.
Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

[Syntax: ANCHOR='anchor-name'] 
          
Specifies a unique base name for the anchor tag that identifies each 
output object in the current body file.

[Syntax: ARCHIVE='string'] 
          
The ARCHIVE= option is only valid for the GOPTIONS Java device. The ARCHIVE= 
option allows you to specify a string to identify which applet to use in order 
to view the ODS HTML output.

[Syntax: ATTRIBUTES=(attribute-pair-1 ... attribute-pair-n)] 
          
Writes the specified attributes between the tags that generate dynamic 
graphics output.

[Syntax: BASE= 'base-text'] 
          
Specifies the text to use as the first part of all links and references that 
ODS creates in the output files.

[Syntax: BODY= 'file-specification' <sub-option(s)>] 
          
Opens a MARKUP family destination and specifies the file that contains the primary 
output that is created by the ODS statement.

[Syntax: CHARSET=character-set] 
          
Specifies the character set to be generated in the META declaration for the HTML output.

[Syntax: CODE= 'file-specification' <sub-option(s)>] 
          
Opens a MARKUP family destination and specifies the file that contains relevant style 
information, such as XSL (Extensible Stylesheet Language).

[Syntax: CODEBASE='string'] 
          
Creates a file path that is used by the GOPTIONS devices.

Syntax: CONTENTS= 'file-specification' <(suboption(s))> 
          
Opens a markup family destination and specifies the file that contains a table of contents for 
the output. These files remain open until you do one of the following:

  o close the destination with either an ODS markup-family-destination CLOSE statement or ODS _ALL_ CLOSE statement.

  o open the same destination with a second markup family statement. This closes the first file and opens 
    the second file.

file-specification -- specifies the file, fileref, or SAS catalog to write to. 

  file-specification is one of the following:

  external-file --  is the name of an external file to write to.
  Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

  fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to 
  assign a fileref. 

  entry.markup -- specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to. 

suboption(s) -- specifies one or more suboptions in parentheses. Suboptions are instructions for 
writing the output files.

Specifies the name of a device driver. ODS automatically selects an optimal default 
device for each open output destination.

[Syntax: ENCODING=local-character-set-encoding] 
          
Overrides the encoding for input or output processing (transcodes) of external files.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Arabic
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Baltic

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: EVENT=event-name (FILE= | FINISH | LABEL= | NAME= | START | STYLE= |TARGET= | TEXT= | URL= )
    
Specifies an event and the value for event variables that are associated with the event.

Syntax: FRAME='file-specification' <sub-option(s)> 
    
Opens a MARKUP family destination and, for HTML output, specifies the file that integrates the table 
of contents, the page contents, and the body file.

Prints footnotes that are created by SAS/GRAPH, the SGPLOT procedure, the SGPANEL procedure, or the 
SGSCATTER procedure. The footnotes appear inside the graph borders.  If you open the frame file, 
then you see a table of contents, a table of pages, or both, as well as the body file. For XLM 
output, FRAME= specifies the file that contains the DTD. These files remain open until you do 
one of the following:

  o close the destination with either an ODS markup-family-destination CLOSE statement or ODS _ALL_ CLOSE statement.

  o open the same destination with a second markup family statement. This closes the first file and opens the second file.

file-specification 
specifies the file, fileref, or SAS catalog to write to. file-specification is one of the following:

    external-file -- is the name of an external file to write to.
    Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

    fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. 

    entry.markup -- specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to. 

suboption(s) 
specifies one or more suboptions in parentheses. Suboptions are instructions for writing the output files.
Prints footnotes that are created by ODS, which appears outside the graph borders.

Syntax: GPATH= 'aggregate-file-storage-specification' | fileref | libref.catalog (URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE)  
   
Specifies the location for all graphics output that is generated while the destination is open. 

  'aggregate-file-storage-location' 
  specifies an aggregate storage location such as directory, folder, or partitioned data set.
  Requirement: You must enclose aggregate-file-storage-location in quotation marks. 

  fileref 
  is a file reference that has been assigned to an aggregate storage location. Use the FILENAME 
  statement to assign a fileref.

  libref.catalog -- specifies a SAS catalog to write to.

  URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE --  specifies a URL for file-specification. 

    Uniform-Resource-Locator -- is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in 
    all the links and references that it creates to the file.
    Requirement: You must enclose Uniform-Resource-Locator in quotation marks. 

    NONE -- specifies that no information from the GPATH= option appears in the links or references.

Prints the title that is created by SAS/GRAPH, the SGPLOT procedure, the SGPANEL procedure, or the 
SGSCATTER procedure. The title appears inside the graph borders.
Prints the title that is created by ODS, which appears outside the graph borders.

Specifies tags to place between the <HEAD> and </HEAD> tags in all the files that the destination 
writes to. 

Syntax: HEADTEXT= 'markup-document-head' 

where:

  markup-document-head 
  specifies the markup tags to place between the <HEAD> and </HEAD> tags.

  Requirement: You must enclose markup-document-head in quotation marks.

[Syntax: (ID=identifier)] 
          
Enables you to run multiple instances of the same destination at the same time. 
Each instance can have different options.

Specifies the image resolution for graphical output. Default: 100. 
          
Restriction: The IMAGE_DPI= option affects template-based graphics only.

Specifies HTML code to use as the <META> tag between the <HEAD> and </HEAD> tags of all the HTML 
files that the destination writes to. 

Syntax: METATEXT= 'metatext-for-document-head' 

where:

  'metatext-for-document-head' 
  specifies the HTML code that provides the browser with information about the document that it is loading. 
  For example, this attribute could specify the content type and the character set to use.

  Requirement: You must enclose metatext-for-document-head in quotation marks.

[Syntax: NEWFILE=starting-point] 
          
Creates a new body file at the specified starting-point.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Starts a new file for the results of each BY group.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Writes all output to the body file that is currently open.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Starts a new body file for each output object.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Starts a new body file for each page of output.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Starts a new body file each time that you start a new procedure.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: OPTIONS ( DOC= | <suboption(s)> )] 
          
Specifies tagset-specific suboptions and a named value.

(DOC='QUICK' | 'HELP' | 'SETTINGS') 
provides information about the specified tagset. 

  QUICK 
  describes the options available for this tagset. 

  HELP 
  provides generic help and information with a quick reference.

  SETTINGS 
  provides the current option settings.

suboption(s) 
specifies one or more suboptions that are valid for the specified tagset. Suboptions have the 
following format: 

  keyword='value'  
  You can get information about suboptions for a specific tagset by specifying one of the following 
  options when opening an ODS tagset statement or at any time after the destination has been opened. 
    
    options(doc='help');
    options(doc='quick'); 
    options(doc='settings');

[Syntax: PACKAGE <package-name>] 
          
Specifies that the output from the destination be added to a package.

Syntax: PAGE= 'file-specification' <(suboption(s))> 
          
Opens a markup family destination and specifies the file that contains a description of each 
page of the body file, and contains links to the body file. ODS produces a new page of output 
whenever a procedure requests a new page. These files remain open until you do one of the following:

  o close the destination with either an ODS markup-family-destination CLOSE statement or 
    ODS _ALL_ CLOSE statement.

  o open the same destination with a second markup family statement. This closes the first file 
    and opens the second file.

file-specification 
specifies the file, fileref, or SAS catalog to write to. 

    file-specification is one of the following:

    external-file -- is the name of an external file to write to.
    Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

    fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME 
    statement to assign a fileref. 

    entry.markup -- specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to. 
    Interaction: If you specify an entry name, you must also specify a library and catalog.  

suboption(s) 
specifies one or more suboptions in parentheses. Suboptions are instructions for writing the output files.

Syntax: PARAMETERS=(parameter-pair-1 ... parameter-pair-n) 
          
Writes the specified parameters between the tags that generate dynamic graphics output.

  parameter-pair 
  specifies the name and value of each parameter. parameter-pair has the following form: 

    'parameter-name'= 'parameter-value'  

  where:
  
  parameter-name -- is the name of the parameter.

  parameter-value -- is the value of the parameter.
  Requirement: You must enclose parameter-name and parameter-value in quotation marks.

Syntax: PATH= 'aggregate-file-storage-specification' | fileref | libref.catalog (URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE) 
   
Specifies the location of an aggregate storage location or a SAS catalog for all markup files. 
If the GPATH= option is not specified, all graphics output files are written to the 
"aggregate-file-storage-specification" or libref.

  'aggregate-file-storage-location' -- specifies an aggregate storage location such as directory, folder, or partitioned data set.
  Requirement: You must enclose aggregate-file-storage-location in quotation marks. 

  fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an aggregate storage location. 
  Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref.

    Interaction: If you use a fileref in the PATH= option, then ODS does not use information from 
    PATH= when it constructs links. 

  libref.catalog -- specifies a SAS catalog to write to.

  URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE -- specifies a URL for the file-specification. 

    Uniform-Resource-Locator 
    is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references that it creates to the file.

    NONE 
    specifies that no information from the PATH= option appears in the links or references.

Syntax: RECORD_SEPARATOR= 'alternative-separator' | NONE 
    
Specifies an alternative character or string that separates lines in the output files.

Different operating environments use different separator characters. If you do not specify a record 
separator, then the files are formatted for the environment where you run the SAS job. However, 
if you are generating files for viewing in a different operating environment that uses a different 
separator character, then you can specify a record separator that is appropriate for the target environment.

alternative-separator -- represents one or more characters in hexadecimal or ASCII format. For example, 
the following option specifies a record separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character 
for use with an ASCII file system: 

  RECORD_SEPARATOR= '0D0A'x
  
Operating Environment Information:   In a mainframe environment, the option that specifies a record 
separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character for use with an ASCII file system is: 

  RECORD_SEPARATOR= '0D25'x
  Requirement: You must enclose alternative-separator in quotation marks. 

NONE -- produces the markup language that is appropriate for the environment where you run the SAS job.

[Syntax: STYLE= style-definition] 
          
Specifies the style definition to use in writing the output files.

Syntax: STYLESHEET= 'file-specification' <sub-option(s)> 
    
Opens a markup family destination and places the style information for markup output into an external 
file, or reads style sheet information from an existing file. These files remain open until you do one 
of the following:

  o close the destination with either an ODS markup-family-destination CLOSE statement or ODS _ALL_ CLOSE statement.

  o open the same destination with a second markup family statement. This closes the first file and opens the second file.

file-specification -- specifies the file, fileref, or SAS catalog to write to. 

file-specification is one of the following:

    external-file 
    is the name of an external file to write to.
    Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

    fileref 
    is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. 

    entry.markup -- specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to.
    Interaction: If you specify an entry name, you must also specify a library and catalog. See the discussion 
    of the PATH= option. 

suboption(s) -- specifies one or more suboptions in parentheses.

Specifies a keyword value for a tagset. A tagset is a template that defines how to create an output 
type from a SAS format.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Produces compact, minimal HTML output that does not use style information.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Contains a table of Unicode values and mnemonics.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Produces tabular output that contains  columns of data values that are separated by commas.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Produces tabular output with titles that contain columns of data values that are separated by commas.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Produces output with comma-separated values and columns of data that are separated by commas.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Produces XML output that conforms to the DocBook DTD by OASIS.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Produces Microsoft's spreadsheetML XML. This tagset is used to import data into XML.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip10: produces HTML output with cascading style sheets that is similar to ODS HTML output.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip12: produces HTML output as a column of output that is separated by lines.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip13: Produces HTML code for output generated by ODS for Microsoft Office products.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip14: Produces URLs within HTML files that are used in the z/OS operating environment.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip15: Produces simple HTML output that uses twelve style elements and no class attributes.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip16: Produces PYX, which is a simple, line-oriented notation used by Pyxie to describe the information  communicated by an XML parser to an XML application.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip18: Causes imbedded data to be produced in CSV format.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip19: Uses the Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) to produce a Wireless Markup Language (WML) DTD with  a list of URLs as a table of contents.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip20: Uses the Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) to produce a Wireless Markup Language (WML) DTD with  an option list for the table of contents.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip22: Creates XML output that shows which events are being triggered and which variables are used by an  event to send output from a SAS process to an output file.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip23: Creates HTML output similar to STYLE_POPUP, but with all the objects labeled as they are when  using ODS TRACE.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip24: Creates a subset of the XML output that is created by the EVENT_MAP tagset.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip25: Creates a sample page of HTML output that is similar to STYLE_POPUP output.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip26: Creates HTML like HTMLCSS, but if you're using Internet Explorer, STYLE_POPUP displays a window  that shows the resolved ODS style definition for any item that you select.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip27: Creates text output that shows which events are being triggered as ODS handles the output objects.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip28: Creates HTML output in a bulleted list similar to EVENT_MAP but lists only a subset of the  possible attributes.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip29: Creates XML output similar to EVENT_MAP but lists only a subset of the possible attributes.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: TEXT='variable-value'] 
          
Inserts text into your document by triggering the paragraph event and specifying 
a text string to be assigned to the VALUE event variable.

Syntax: TRANTAB= 'translation-table' 
          
Specifies the translation table to use when transcoding a file for output.

Syntax: EXCLUDE exclusion(s)| ALL | NONE 
          
Excludes output objects from the destination.
Closes the destination and any files that are associated with it.
See the EXCLUDE or SELECT option.
See the EXCLUDE or SELECT option.

Syntax: SELECT selection(s) | ALL | NONE 
          
Selects output objects for the specified destination.
Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

[Syntax: ANCHOR='anchor-name'] 
          
Specifies the root name for the anchor tag that identifies each output object 
in the current file.

[Syntax: AUTHOR='author-text'] 
          
Inserts into the metadata of a file, the text string that you specify as the author.

Specifies the text to use as the first part of all references that ODS creates in the output files.

Syntax: BASE= 'base-text'

base-text 
is the text that ODS uses as the first part of all references that ODS creates in the file.

Consider this specification: 

BASE='http://www.your-company.com/local-url/'
In this case, ODS creates references that begin with the string http://www.your-company.com/local-url/. 
The appropriate anchor-name completes the link.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Generates a list of bookmarks for your PDF file. The bookmarks are not automatically displayed when  you open the PDF file.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies not to generate a list of bookmarks for your PDF file.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Generates a list of bookmarks for your PDF file. The bookmarks are automatically displayed when you  open the PDF file.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies whether to generate and display the list of bookmarks for a PDF file.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies not to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Controls the generation of bookmarks in a PDF file.
Specifies to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.
Specifies not to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Creates full color output for both text and graphics.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Creates gray scale output for both text and graphics.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Creates monochromatic output for both text and graphics.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Does not use all the color information that the style definition provides.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Uses all the color information that a style definition provides, including background color.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Applies the specified color scheme to your output.

[Syntax: COLUMNS=n] 
          
Specifies the number of columns to place across each page of output. 
            
n 
is the number columns per page.

Default: 1

[Syntax: COMPRESS=n] 
          
Controls the compression of a PDF file. Compression reduces the size of the file.
            
n 
specifies the level of compression. The larger the number, the greater the compression. For example,
n=0 is completely uncompressed, and n=9 is the maximum compression level. 

Default: 6 
Range: 0-9
Controls the generation of a printable table of contents.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Does not generate a printable table of contents.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Generates a printable table of contents.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Generates a printable table of contents page.
Does not generate a printable table of contents.

Syntax: CSSSTYLE='file-specification'<(media-type-1 <...media-type-10>)> 
    
Specifies a cascading style sheet to apply to your output. 

file-specification 
specifies a file, fileref, or URL that contains CSS code. 

    file-specification is one of the following:

    "external-file" 
    is the name of the external file.
    Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

    fileref 
    is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. 

    "URL" 
    is a URL to an external file.
    Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

(media-type-1<.. media-type-10>) 
specifies one or more media blocks that corresponds to the type of media that your output will be 
rendered on. CSS uses media type blocks to specify how a document is to be presented on different 
media: on the screen, on paper, with a speech synthesizer, with a braille device, and so on.

Specifies the image resolution for output files. Default: 150 
          
Restriction: The DPI= option takes effect only if specified at the opening of a file.

Syntax: FILE='external-file' | fileref 
          
Specifies the file that contains the output. 

  external-file 
  is the name of an external file to write to.
  Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

  fileref 
  is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement 
  to assign a fileref.

Specifies that ODS use the printer drivers that the host system provides. 
          
Interaction: In an ODS printer family statement that refers to an open ODS PRINTER destination, 
the HOST option forces ODS to close the destination and all files that are associated with it, 
and to open a new instance of the destination.

[Syntax: KEYWORDS='keywords-text'] 
          
Inserts into the output file's metadata, a string of keywords. 
          
Restriction: Use this option only with the ODS PDF statement, the ODS PS statement with the PDFMARK 
option specified, and the ODS PRINTER statement with the PDFMARK option specified. 

Restriction: The KEYWORDS= option takes effect only if specified at the opening of a file. 

Requirement: You must enclose keywords-text in quotation marks.

[Syntax: (<ID=>identifier)] 
          
Enables you to open multiple instances of the same destination at the same time. Each 
instance can have different options.
Creates a new file at the specified starting-point.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Starts a new file for the results of each BY group.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Writes all output to the file that is currently open.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Starts a new file for each output object. For SAS/GRAPH this means that ODS creates a new file  for each SAS/GRAPH output file that the program generates.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Starts a new file for each page of output. A page break occurs when a procedure explicitly starts  a new page (not because the page size was exceeded) or when you start a new procedure.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Starts a body file each time that you start a new procedure.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that ODS omit the table of contents (Bookmark list) that is produced by 
default when producing PDF or PDFMARK output. 

Interaction: The NOTOC option specifies BOOKMARKLIST=OFF and CONTENTS= OFF.

[Syntax: PACKAGE <package-name>] 
          
Specifies that the output from the destination be added to a package. 
          
package-name 
specifies the name of a package that was created with the ODS PACKAGE statement. If no name 
is specified, then the output is added to the unnamed package that was opened last.

Creates PCL output. 
         
Restriction: Do not use this option in conjunction with the PDF or PS option. 

Interaction: If you use the PCL option in an ODS PRINTER statement that refers to an open 
ODS PRINTER destination, the option will force ODS to close the destination and all files 
that are associated with it, and to open a new instance of the destination.

Creates PDF output. 
          
Restriction: Do not use this option in conjunction with the PCL or PS option. 

Interaction: If you use the PDF option in an ODS PRINTER statement that refers to an open 
ODS PRINTER destination, the option will force ODS to close the destination and all files 
that are associated with it, and to open a new instance of the destination.]

Enables ODS to insert special tags into a PostScript file. When you use software 
such as Adobe Acrobat (not Adobe Viewer), Acrobat Distiller interprets the tags 
to create a PDF file that contains the following items: 

  o bookmarks for each section of the output and for each table.

  o references for items that are associated with the URL= style attribute.

  o notes for items that are associated with the FLYOVER= style attribute. 
    Notes are optional, and are based on the PDFNOTE option.

  o author, keywords, subject, and title in the metadata of a file.
Adds notes to a PDF file for items that are associated with the FLYOVER= style attribute.

Modifies the behavior of PDFMARK so that notes are not added to the file for items that 
are associated with the FLYOVER= style attribute.

[Syntax: PDFTOC=n] 
          
Controls the level of the expansion of the table of contents in PDF documents.

[Syntax: PRINTER=printer-name] 
          
Creates output that is formatted for the specified printer. 
          
Default: If you do not specify a printer, then ODS formats the printer output for the printer 
that is specified by one of two SAS system options: 
  
  o SYSPRINT= if you are using the Windows operating environment and do not specify any of the
    following options: PCL, PDFMARK, POSTSCRIPT, PS, or SAS.

  o PRINTERPATH= in all other cases.
 
Restriction: printer-name must match a subkey in either the SAS registry or the Windows printer registry.
Creates PostScript output.
Controls page breaks.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies not to insert page breaks, even before graphics procedures.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that no new pages be inserted at the beginning of each procedure, or within certain  procedures, even if new pages are requested by the procedure code. A new page will begin only  when a page is filled or when you specify STARTPAGE=NOW.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Forces the immediate insertion of a new page.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Inserts a new page at the beginning of each procedure, and within certain procedures, as requested  by the procedure code.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: STYLE=style-definition] 
          
Specifies the style definition to use in writing the printer output.

[Syntax: SUBJECT='subject-text'] 
          
Inserts into the metadata of a file the text string that you specify as the subject.

subject-text 
is the text in the metadata of a file that indicates the subject.

Restriction: Use this option only with the ODS PDF statement, the ODS PS statement with the 
PDFMARK option specified, and the ODS PRINTER statement with the PDFMARK option specified. 

Restriction: The SUBJECT= option takes effect only if specified at the opening of a file. 

Requirement: You must enclose subject-text in quotation marks.

[Syntax: TEXT='text-string'] 
          
Inserts a text string into your output. 
          
Requirement: You must enclose text-string in quotation marks.

[Syntax: TITLE='title-text'] 
          
Inserts into the metadata of a file, the text string that you specify as the title. 

Restriction: Use this option only with the ODS PDF statement, the ODS PS statement with the 
PDFMARK option specified, and the ODS PRINTER statement with the PDFMARK option specified. 

Restriction: The TITLE= option takes effect only if specified at the opening of a file. 

Requirement: You must enclose title-text in quotation marks.

For multiple page tables, ensures uniformity from page to page within a single table. When the UNIFORM 
option is in effect, ODS reads the entire table before it starts to print it so that it can determine 
the column widths that are necessary to accommodate all the data. These column widths are applied to 
all pages of a multiple page table. 

Note: With BY-group processing, SAS writes the results of each BY group to a separate table, so the 
output might not be uniform across BY groups.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ODS PROCTITLE; 
      
Writes, in the output, the name of the procedure that produces the results.

Syntax: ODS NOPROCTITLE;
      
Suppresses the writing of the title of the procedure that produces the results.

Enables you to change a procedure label.
      
Syntax: ODS PROCLABEL 'string';
      
where:

'string' is the procedure label that you specify.

Syntax: ODS RESULTS ON | OFF; 
      
Tracks ODS output in the Results window.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Tracks output that ODS generates in the Results window.
Turns off the tracking of output that ODS generates in the Results window.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Inserts text into your ODS output. 
      
Syntax: ODS TEXT= 'text-string';
      
where:

text-string
specifies the text to insert into your output. This text is sent to all open supported output destinations.

Restriction:  The ODS TEXT= statement does not support the OUTPUT destination or the LISTING destination. 
All other ODS destinations are supported. 

Requirement:  You must enclose 'text-string' in parentheses. 

Tip:  The UserText style element controls text specified with the TEXT= statement.
Syntax: ODS TRACE ON </option(s)>; |  ODS TRACE OFF;

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Turns on the writing of the trace record.
Turns off the writing of the trace record.
Includes, in the trace record, information for excluded output objects.

Includes the label path for the output object in the record. You can use a label path 
anywhere that you can use a path.

Writes the trace record to the Listing destination, so that each part of the trace record 
immediately precedes the output object that it describes.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ODS USEGOPT; 
      
Specifies that ODS use traditional SAS/GRAPH option settings for non-graphical output.

Syntax: ODS NOUSEGOPT; 
      
Specifies that ODS not use traditional SAS/GRAPH option settings for non-graphical output.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Prints the warning and sends output objects to open destinations.
Suppresses the warning.

Prints an error message instead of a warning message and does not send output objects 
to open destinations.
Prints a warning message and does not send output objects to open destinations.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Defines a representative character to be used in output strings.
      
Syntax: ODS ESCAPECHAR= 'escape-character';

escape-character 
specifies the special character that identifies the inline formatting symbol. The escape-character 
should be one of the following rarely used characters: @, ^, or \.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: EXCLUDE exclusion(s)| ALL | NONE 
          
Excludes output objects from the RTF destination.
Closes the RTF destination and any files that are associated with it.
See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.
See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.

Syntax: SELECT selection(s) | ALL | NONE 
          
Selects output objects for the RTF destination.
Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

[Syntax: ANCHOR='anchor-name'] 
          
Specifies the base name for the RTF anchor tag that identifies each output object 
in the current file.

[Syntax: AUTHOR='author-text'] 
          
Inserts the text string that you specify as the author into the metadata of a file.

Specifies the text to use as the first part of all references that ODS creates        
in the output files.

Syntax: BASE= 'base-text'

base-text 
is the text that ODS uses as the first part of all references that ODS creates in the file.

Consider this specification: 

BASE='http://www.your-company.com/local-url/'
In this case, ODS creates references that begin with the string http://www.your-company.com/local-url/. 
The appropriate anchor-name completes the link.

Specifies that SAS titles and footnotes are placed into the body of the RTF document instead of into 
the headers and footers section of the RTF document.

Restriction: The BODYTITLE option can be specified only when you create a new RTF file.

Specifies that SAS titles and footnotes be placed into the body of the RTF document instead of into 
the headers and footers section of the RTF document. These titles and footnotes are put into cells, 
which allows titles and footnotes to be centered, left-justified, or right-justified.

Restriction: You can specify the BODYTITLE_AUX option only when you are creating a new RTF file.

[Syntax: COLUMNS=n | MAX] 
          
Specifies the number of columns to place across each page of output. 
            
Default: the number of one-inch columns that fit on the page.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Is the number of one-inch columns that you want on the page.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the maximum number of one-inch-wide columns for the paper size and margin setting.  This value is dependent upon the paper size and page orientation.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Produces a table of contents page for RTF documents that are opened in Microsoft Word. The table of 
contents page contains a Table of Contents field, which puts all of the contents information that is 
embedded in the document into a table of contents. To expand the table of contents, right-click under 
the title in Microsoft Word and select Update Field from the selection list. 

Restriction: Do not use the CONTENTS option with the NEWFILE option.

Syntax: CSSSTYLE='file-specification'<(media-type-1 <...media-type-10>)> 
    
Specifies a cascading style sheet to apply to your output. 

file-specification 
specifies a file, fileref, or URL that contains CSS code. 

    file-specification is one of the following:

    "external-file" 
    is the name of the external file.
    Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

    fileref 
    is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. 

    "URL" 
    is a URL to an external file.
    Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

(media-type-1<.. media-type-10>) 
specifies one or more media blocks that corresponds to the type of media that your output will be 
rendered on. CSS uses media type blocks to specify how a document is to be presented on different 
media: on the screen, on paper, with a speech synthesizer, with a braille device, and so on.

Specifies the name of a device driver. ODS automatically selects an optimal default 
device for each open output destination.

[Syntax: ENCODING=local-character-set-encoding] 
          
Overrides the encoding for input or output processing (transcodes) of external files.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Arabic
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Baltic

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Opens the RTF destination and specifies the RTF file or SAS catalog to which to 
write. This file remains open until you do one of the following actions:

  o Close the RTF destination with ODS RTF CLOSE or ODS _ALL_ CLOSE.

  o Specify a different file to which to write.

Syntax: FILE= 'external-file' | fileref

  'external-file' 
  is the name of an external file to which to write.

  fileref 
  is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file.
Includes all of the currently defined footnotes within the graphics output.

Prevents all of the currently defined footnotes from appearing in the graphics file. 
Instead, they become part of the RTF file.

Includes all of the currently defined titles within the graphics output that is called 
by the body file.

Prevents all of the currently defined titles from appearing in the graphics output. 
Instead, the titles become part of the RTF file.

[Syntax: (ID=identifier)] 
          
Enables you to run multiple instances of the same destination at the same 
time. Each instance can have different options.

Specifies the image resolution for graphical output. Default: 200. 
          
Restriction: The IMAGE_DPI= option affects template-based graphics only.
ODS allows table splits only if the entire table cannot fit on one page.
ODS lets a table split at a page break.

[Syntax: NEWFILE=starting-point] 
                    
Creates a new file at the specified starting-point.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Starts a new file for the results of each BY group.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Writes all output to the body file that is currently open.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Starts a new body file for each output object.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Starts a new body file for each page of output.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Starts a new body file each time that you start a new procedure.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Instructs ODS not to insert contents data into the RTF file.

[Syntax: OPERATOR= 'text-string'] 
          
Inserts the text you specify into the metadata of the RTF file.

[Syntax: PACKAGE <package-name>] 
          
Specifies that the output from the destination be added to a package. 
          
package-name 
specifies the name of a package that was created with the ODS PACKAGE statement. If no name 
is specified, then the output is added to the unnamed package that was opened last.

Syntax: PATH= 'aggregate-file-storage-specification' | fileref | libref.catalog (URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE) 
   
Specifies the location of an aggregate storage location or a SAS catalog for all markup files. 
If the GPATH= option is not specified, all graphics output files are written to the 
"aggregate-file-storage-specification" or libref.

  'aggregate-file-storage-location' -- specifies an aggregate storage location such as directory, folder, or partitioned data set.
  Requirement: You must enclose aggregate-file-storage-location in quotation marks. 

  fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an aggregate storage location. 
  Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref.

    Interaction: If you use a fileref in the PATH= option, then ODS does not use information from 
    PATH= when it constructs links. 

  libref.catalog -- specifies a SAS catalog to write to.

  URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE -- specifies a URL for the file-specification. 

    Uniform-Resource-Locator 
    is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references 
    that it creates to the file.

    NONE 
    specifies that no information from the PATH= option appears in the links or references.

Syntax: RECORD_SEPARATOR= 'alternative-separator' | NONE 
    
Specifies an alternative character or string that separates lines in the output files.

Different operating environments use different separator characters. If you do not specify a record 
separator, then the files are formatted for the environment where you run the SAS job. However, 
if you are generating files for viewing in a different operating environment that uses a different 
separator character, then you can specify a record separator that is appropriate for the target environment.

alternative-separator -- represents one or more characters in hexadecimal or ASCII format. For example, 
the following option specifies a record separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character 
for use with an ASCII file system: 

  RECORD_SEPARATOR= '0D0A'x
  
Operating Environment Information:   In a mainframe environment, the option that specifies a record 
separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character for use with an ASCII file system is: 

  RECORD_SEPARATOR= '0D25'x
  Requirement: You must enclose alternative-separator in quotation marks. 

NONE -- produces the markup language that is appropriate for the environment where you run the SAS job.

Writes to the RTF file the time and the date that you started your SAS session. 

Restriction: You can specify SASDATE only when you open a new file. If you specify the option 
at any other time, ODS writes a warning message to the SAS log.
Controls page breaks.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Inserts a new page at the beginning of each procedure, and within certain procedures, as requested  by the procedure code.

Syntax: OPTIONS (CONTENTS= | DOC= | SECT= | TABLES_OFF= |TOC_DATA= |TROWD= |TRHDR= | TROWHDRCELL= ) 
          
Specifies ODS TAGSETS.RTF specific suboptions and a named value. 

(CONTENTS= 'YES') 
produces a table of contents (TOC) page for RTF documents that are opened in Microsoft Word.

(DOC='QUICK' | 'HELP' | 'SETTINGS') 
provides information about the tagset.

(SECT='rtf_control_string' | 'OFF' | 'NONE') 
inserts RTF control words into the section data specifications.

TABLES_OFF='style_elements' | 'STYLE_ELEMENTS' | 'OFF' ) 
determines whether tables will be used. 

(TOC_DATA ='ON' | 'OFF') 
specifies whether to show the contents data in the RTF file.

(TROWD='rtf_control_string' | ' OFF') 
inserts raw RTF specifications directly into header descriptions of the table row.

(TRHDR='rtf_control_string' | 'OFF') 

TROWHDRCELL='text_string' | 'OFF')
Specifies the number of panels permitted per page before ODS inserts a page break.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies a positive integer. Replace n with an actual value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that paneling will be handled the way that it has always been handled by traditional ODS RTF.  That is, all of the first panel is written, then all of the second panel, and so on, until all of the  table information is written.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: TABLEROWS= n] 
          
Specifies the number of rows in each table before ODS inserts a page break. If the 
table is narrow enough to fit on a page, n lines will be written to the table before 
a page break. If the table is too wide for a page, the page is broken into panels. In 
each panel, n rows will be written. When all the panels for n rows have been written, 
a page break is inserted before the next group of panels is written.
Ensures uniformity from page to page within a single table that requires multiple pages.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: SIGNON <options> ;
    
Initiates a connection between a client session and a server session.

Syntax: SIGNOFF <options> 
    
Ends the connection between a client session and a server session.

Marks the end of a block of statements that a client session submits to a server session 
for execution.

Syntax: LISTTASK <_ALL_|task> ; 
    
Lists all active connections or tasks and identifies the execution status of each connection or task.

Syntax: KILLTASK _ALL_ |task1...taskn ;
    
For asynchronous tasks, forces one or more active tasks or server sessions to terminate immediately.

Syntax: WAITFOR<_ANY_ | _ALL_> taskname <taskname...><TIMEOUT=seconds>;
    
Suspends execution of the current SAS session until the specified tasks finish executing.
